summary.para: Contains information used to uniquely identify an application. This class cannot be inherited.

content.para: An application identity consists of the publisher's public key, the application name, the target processor architecture, the application culture, and the application version. The application identity properties values correspond to information contained in the application manifest.
T:System.ApplicationId is used by the T:System.Security.Policy.ApplicationSecurityInfo class to identify an application.

The following code example displays the T:System.ApplicationId properties by obtaining the T:System.ApplicationId from an T:System.Security.Policy.ApplicationSecurityInfo instance created using the T:System.ActivationContext for the currently executing manifest-based application.

summary.para: Initializes a new instance of the T:System.ApplicationId class.

content.para: The array of bytes representing the raw public key data.
The name of the application.
A T:System.Version object that specifies the version of the application.
The processor architecture of the application.
The culture of the application.

The constructor initializes the P:System.ApplicationId.Culture, P:System.ApplicationId.Name, P:System.ApplicationId.ProcessorArchitecture, P:System.ApplicationId.PublicKeyToken, and P:System.ApplicationId.Version properties of the T:System.ApplicationId.

summary.para: Creates and returns an identical copy of the current application identity.

returnValue.para: An T:System.ApplicationId object that represents an exact copy of the original.

content.para: The copy returned by this method is equal to the original as substantiated by the M:System.ApplicationId.Equals(System.Object) method. The hash codes for the original and the copy are also equal.

summary.para: Gets a string representing the culture information for the application.

returnValue.para: The culture information for the application.

content.para: The P:System.ApplicationId.Culture value can include language information, for example, "en-US".
For information about culture values, see T:System.Globalization.CultureInfo.

The following code example displays the P:System.ApplicationId.Culture property by obtaining the T:System.ApplicationId from an T:System.Security.Policy.ApplicationSecurityInfo instance created using the T:System.ActivationContext for the currently executing manifest-based application. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the T:System.ApplicationId class.

summary.para: Determines whether the specified T:System.ApplicationId object is equivalent to the current T:System.ApplicationId.

content.para: The T:System.ApplicationId object to compare to the current T:System.ApplicationId.

returnValue.para: true if the specified T:System.ApplicationId object is equivalent to the current T:System.ApplicationId; otherwise, false.

content.para: This method overrides the M:System.Object.Equals(System.Object) method.

summary.para: Determines whether two objects are equal.
Gets the hash code for the current application identity.

returnValue.para: The hash code for the current application identity.

content.para: This method generates the same hash code for two objects that have the same values for their P:System.ApplicationId.Name and P:System.ApplicationId.Version properties.

summary.para: Gets the name of the application.

content.para: P:System.ApplicationId.Name is the simple, unencrypted name of the application.

The following code example displays the P:System.ApplicationId.Name property by obtaining the T:System.ApplicationId from an T:System.Security.Policy.ApplicationSecurityInfo instance created using the T:System.ActivationContext for the currently executing manifest-based application. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the T:System.ApplicationId class.

summary.para: Gets the target processor architecture for the application.

returnValue.para: The processor architecture of the application.

content.para: Valid values include "msil", "x86", "ia64", and "amd64". The default is "msil", or Microsoft intermediate language, which means all your assemblies are platform independent, and the common language runtime will compile them when they are needed by your application.

The following code example displays the P:System.ApplicationId.ProcessorArchitecture property by obtaining the T:System.ApplicationId from an T:System.Security.Policy.ApplicationSecurityInfo instance created using the T:System.ActivationContext for the currently executing manifest-based application. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the T:System.ApplicationId class.

summary.para: Gets the public key token for the application.

returnValue.para: A byte array containing the public key token for the application.

content.para: The public key token is represented by the last 8 bytes of the SHA-1 hash of the public key under which the application is signed.
For more information, see M:System.Reflection.AssemblyName.GetPublicKeyToken.

The following code example displays the P:System.ApplicationId.PublicKeyToken property by obtaining the T:System.ApplicationId from an T:System.Security.Policy.ApplicationSecurityInfo instance created using the T:System.ActivationContext for the currently executing manifest-based application. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the T:System.ApplicationId class.

summary.para: Creates and returns a string representation of the application identity.

returnValue.para: A string representation of the application identity.

content.para: This method overrides the M:System.Object.ToString method.

summary.para: Gets the version of the application.

returnValue.para: A T:System.Version that specifies the version of the application.

content.para: For more information, see T:System.Version.

The following code example displays the P:System.ApplicationId.Version property by obtaining the T:System.ApplicationId from an T:System.Security.Policy.ApplicationSecurityInfo instance created using the T:System.ActivationContext for the currently executing manifest-based application. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the T:System.ApplicationId class.

summary.para: Determines whether two objects are equal.
